title: Epidemiological and evolutionary models for invasion and persistence of disease
abstractText: Abstracts are not currently available in GtR for all funded research. This is normally because the abstract was not required at the time of proposal submission, but may be because it included sensitive information such as personal details.
impactText: The research is at an early stage in that it has identified what factors need to be considered in selecting plants for resistance to plant pathogens in such a manner as to minimise risks of failure. Agriculture, Food and Drink,Environment
findingsText:
Novel methods developed to study the evolutionary ecology of plant pathogens.

Experimental proof for the existence of trade-off relationships between pathogen life-history traits. Three trade-offs were discovered. The field of plant pathology now has the most comprehensive sets of data regarding trade-offs as compared with all other epidemiological disciplines.



The development of evolutionary models allowing for dynamics within and between crops over successive seasons. Combined with the newly discovered trade-off between infection efficiency and survival in the absence of the host one of these models revealed potential differences between air-borne and soil-borne pathogens regarding the direction of selection imposed by such seasonality.



The development of methods to model evolutionary processes in the presence of high local density dependence as a result of multiple infections on the same plant organ. Combined with the newly discovered trade-off between latent period and spore production these modelling techniques showed that multiple infections can lead to shorter latent periods. The group is involved in projects on the management of fungicide resistance funded by (and last year renewed for another 3 years) the Chemicals Regulatory Directorate, CRD, of the UK. We have developed approaches to calculate the effectiveness of fungicide anti-resistance strategies (for example, use of alternation, mixtures, choice of dose, etc.). This modelling work is strongly linked with field experimental studies and we have developed the cycle where experimental data inform modelling, and models suggest the resistance management strategies that are good candidates to be tested in the field. 



Findings from the work are now informing and influencing practical decision making, in liaison with the Fungicide Resistance Action Group, FRA Comittee (representing the crop protection industry), the European Plant Protection Organisation from the EU and CRD. Especially the decisions taken on the recently introduced SDHI fungicides in broad acre crops, and their use as seed treatment, have benefitted from the work. 



Recently the European Plant Protection Organisation asked us to help rewrite/update the European fungicide resistance risk analysis documents. 



We have recently also been invited to help develop a resistance management strategy for fungicide resistance in broad acre crops in Australia where resistance has been confirmed for the first time last year. Since resistance to fungicides in broad acre crops was not an issue before there is little expertise in Australia on resistance management. The methods developed in this project has enabled us to develop project proposals on practically important evolutionary questions. These concentrate on the evolution of plant pathogens to reduce the effectiveness of plant disease control methods such as fungicides and cultivar resistance. Using this the group has been able to write a range of successful grant proposals.
